title: Pacman Frog Substrate Guide: Depth, Mixing, and Bioactive Options
description: Complete substrate guide for Pacman frogs including appropriate types, depth requirements, species-specific mixing ratios (especially C. cranwelli), and bioactive setup options.
author: Habitat Builder
excerpt: Learn proper substrate selection, mixing ratios, depth requirements, and maintenance for all Pacman frog species including C. cranwelli's special sandy substrate needs.

content.heading: Why Substrate Matters for Pacman Frogs
content.text: Pacman frogs burrow as part of their natural behavior and predatory instincts. They are terrestrial ambush predators that bury themselves in substrate and wait for prey. Deep substrate also helps maintain humidity levels. Proper substrate is NOT optional - it's essential for natural behavior and health.
SUBSTRATE REQUIRED - Paper towels, moss-only, bark, or foam prevent natural burrowing behavior. Use only for quarantine/illness/transport. Frogs denied burrowing substrate suffer chronic stress.
The frog must be able to completely burrow out of sight. Depth requirements scale with frog size:
When your frog burrows, you should NOT be able to see any part of it. If you can still see the frog after it burrows, add more substrate.
Substrate must be moist but not waterlogged. Use the squeeze test:

items: Grab a handful of substrate and squeeze it firmly
Water should drip out of the substrate
There should be NO puddles or standing water in the enclosure
Substrate should hold its shape when squeezed
Mix dechlorinated water throughout substrate, don't just mist the surface

content.text: ALL water used (substrate, misting, water dish) must be treated with reptile/amphibian dechlorinator. Chlorine causes toxic shock which is often fatal. Use Zoo Med Reptisafe or Tetra AquaSafe.
Several substrate options work well for Pacman frogs. Choose based on your goals, budget, and species:

content.heading: 1. Coco Fiber / Coco Coir / Eco Earth

content.text: Best for: Budget-conscious keepers, standard tropical species (C. ornata, C. cornuta)
Pros:

items: Soft and comfortable for frogs
Absorbs moisture very well
Holds burrows well
Readily available at pet stores
Affordable ($3-8 per brick)

content.text: Cons:

items: Needs replacement every 3-4 weeks to prevent mold
Not a true soil (lacks nutrients for bioactive)
Can dry out quickly in low humidity
NOT suitable for C. cranwelli (wrong texture)

content.text: Usage: Expand brick with dechlorinated water, break up clumps, perform squeeze test before adding to enclosure. Completely replace every 3-4 weeks.
Best for: Budget-conscious keepers wanting natural substrate, planted tanks, C. cranwelli substrate mixes
Pros:

items: MUCH cheaper than pet store options ($2-5 per 40 lb bag)
True soil that supports live plants
Natural texture and appearance
Can be used in bioactive setups
Required component for C. cranwelli substrate

content.text: Cons:

items: MUST be additive-free, fertilizer-free, and manure-free
Regional variations (check local brands carefully)
Can be harder to find appropriate brands
May need mixing with sand for some species

content.text: Recommended brands: Scott's Premium Topsoil, Timberline Topsoil (brands vary by region - always check ingredients)
For C. cranwelli, mix 60% organic topsoil + 40% play sand. This replicates their Gran Chaco habitat with well-draining sandy soil.
Best for: Keepers wanting convenience, planted tanks, those avoiding big-box store shopping
Pros:

items: Fertilizer-free soil made specifically for reptiles/amphibians
Supports live plants and bioactive setups
No research needed - guaranteed safe ingredients
Lasts longer than coco fiber (2-3 months)
Available at most pet stores

content.text: Cons:

items: More expensive than organic topsoil ($8-15 per bag)
Can become hard-packed (needs fluffing)
May still need sand added for C. cranwelli (60% ReptiSoil, 40% play sand)

content.text: Maintenance: Fluff substrate as it packs down. Replace every 2-3 months in naturalistic setups.
Best for: Keepers committed to bioactive setups with cleanup crew (isopods/springtails)
Options:

items: Josh's Frogs ABG Mix (Atlanta Botanical Garden formula)
The BioDude's Terra Firma Bio Mix
Custom mixes with tree fern fiber, charcoal, sphagnum moss, coco fiber

content.text: Pros:

items: When used with cleanup crew (CUC), substrate NEVER needs replacing
Self-regulating ecosystem processes waste
Enriching for frogs with natural soil fauna
Supports diverse live plant growth
Top off 1-2 times per year (minimal maintenance)

content.text: Cons:

items: EXPENSIVE upfront ($30-60 per bag)
Requires isopods, springtails, and live plants to function
If NOT used as bioactive, still needs replacement every 3-6 months
Not cost-effective for non-bioactive setups
Steeper learning curve for beginners

content.text: Only purchase bioactive substrate mixes if you plan to keep a true bioactive enclosure with cleanup crew. Otherwise, use coco fiber, topsoil, or ReptiSoil for much lower cost.
Cranwell's Horned Frogs live in the Gran Chaco region - an area with well-draining, sandy soil. They require a different substrate mix than other Pacman frog species.
Required Mix: 60% Organic Topsoil + 40% Play Sand
Play sand requirements:

items: MUST be washed sand made for sandboxes (not construction sand)
Quikrete Play Sand is a popular brand
Available at hardware stores for $3-5 per 50 lb bag
Wash sand before mixing if dusty

content.text: Mixing instructions:

items: Use a large container or tub for mixing
Add 6 scoops of organic topsoil
Add 4 scoops of play sand
Mix thoroughly until evenly distributed
Repeat ratio until you have enough substrate
Add dechlorinated water and perform squeeze test
Test: Poke substrate with finger - should retain a hole shape

content.text: This sandy soil is well-draining and can become hard-packed. Fluff it regularly to prevent excessive compaction.
C. cranwelli kept on standard coco fiber or 100% topsoil cannot replicate natural burrowing behavior properly. The sandy mix is NOT optional for this species.
The following substrates are unsafe or prevent natural behavior:

items: Prevents all natural burrowing behavior
Chronic stress from inability to hide properly
ONLY acceptable for: quarantine, illness treatment, transportation
Switch to proper substrate as soon as possible

content.text: Spot cleaning: Remove visible waste daily. Frogs often defecate in water dish - change water daily and clean any contaminated substrate nearby.
Complete replacement: Remove frog to temporary container, dispose of old substrate, clean enclosure with reptile-safe cleaner, add fresh substrate, restore decorations.
Leaf litter should be added ON TOP of whatever substrate you choose. Benefits:

items: Extra enrichment and hiding options
Frogs love burrowing under large leaf pieces
Prevents substrate ingestion during feeding
Provides habitat for cleanup crew in bioactive setups
Natural appearance
Helps maintain humidity

content.text: Recommended leaf litter types:

items: Magnolia leaves (large, durable, long-lasting)
Oak leaves (readily available, natural)
Catappa/Indian almond leaves (beneficial tannins)
Commercial reptile leaf litter mixes

content.text: Replace leaf litter as it breaks down (every 2-4 weeks depending on humidity).
True bioactive enclosures require more than just bioactive substrate. Checklist:

items: Drainage layer (1-2 inches LECA, hydroballs, or gravel with screen barrier)
Bioactive substrate mix (ABG Mix or Terra Firma)
Leaf litter layer on top
Cleanup crew: Dwarf white or powder orange isopods + temperate springtails
Live plants (pothos, ferns, bromeliads)
Patience for ecosystem to establish (4-8 weeks)

content.text: For full bioactive guide, see our Bioactive Enclosure Guide (coming soon).

items: Insufficient depth (frog still visible when burrowed)
Substrate too dry (should drip water when squeezed)
Using untreated tap water (chlorine causes toxic shock)
Replacing bioactive substrate too frequently (disrupts ecosystem)
Using fertilized or manure-containing topsoil (toxic)
C. cranwelli kept on substrate without sand (wrong texture)
No leaf litter (missing enrichment and feeding safety)
Only misting surface instead of mixing water throughout substrate
